definitions.definition: lay hold of (something) with one's hands; reach for and hold.
examples: he leaned forward to take her hand

definitions.definition: remove (someone or something) from a particular place.
examples: he took an envelope from his inside pocket
synonyms: fish "he took an envelope from his pocket"

definitions.definition: consume as food, drink, medicine, or drugs.
examples: take an aspirin and lie down

definitions.definition: capture or gain possession of by force or military means.
examples: twenty of their ships were sunk or taken

definitions.definition: (in bridge, hearts, and similar card games) win (a trick).
capture (an opposing piece or pawn).
dispossess someone of (something); steal or illicitly remove.
examples: someone must have sneaked in here and taken it

definitions.definition: cheat (someone) of something.
examples: can I get taken by buying mutual funds?

definitions.definition: subtract.
examples: take two from ten

definitions.definition: occupy (a place or position).
examples: we found that all the seats were taken
synonyms: engage; informalbag "all the seats had been taken"

definitions.definition: buy or rent (a house).
examples: rent, lease, hire, charter; Morereserve, book, engage "I have taken a room nearby"Morereserve, book, engage I have taken a room nearby

definitions.definition: agree to buy (an item).
examples: I'll take the one on the end
synonyms: vote for "I'd take this over the other option"

definitions.definition: gain or acquire (possession or ownership of something).
examples: he took possession of a unique Picasso ceramic piece
synonyms: pick up "the town takes its name from the lake"

definitions.definition: (of a person) already be married or in an emotional relationship.
use or have ready to use.
examples: take half the marzipan and roll out

definitions.definition: use as an instance or example in support of an argument.
examples: let's take Napoleon, for instance

definitions.definition: regularly buy or subscribe to (a particular newspaper or periodical).
ascertain by measurement or observation.
examples: the nurse takes my blood pressure

definitions.definition: write down.
examples: he was taking notes

definitions.definition: make (a photograph) with a camera.
(especially of illness) suddenly strike or afflict (someone).
examples: he was taken with a seizure of some kind

definitions.definition: have sexual intercourse with.
carry or bring with one; convey.
examples: he took along a portfolio of his drawings
synonyms: tote "I took the package to Wilmington"

definitions.definition: accompany or guide (someone) to a specified place.
examples: I'll take you to your room

definitions.definition: bring into a specified state.
examples: the invasion took Europe to the brink of war

definitions.definition: use as a route or a means of transportation.
examples: take 95 north to Baltimore
synonyms: go via; use "he took the train"

definitions.definition: accept or receive (someone or something).
examples: she was advised to take any job offered
synonyms: take on More"I took the job"receive
scoop "she took the prize for best speaker"

definitions.definition: understand or accept as valid.
examples: I take your point

definitions.definition: acquire or assume (a position, state, or form).
examples: teaching methods will take various forms
synonyms: feel "he took great pleasure in painting"

definitions.definition: achieve or attain (a victory or result).
examples: John Martin took the men's title

definitions.definition: act on (an opportunity).
examples: he took his chance to get out while the house was quiet
synonyms: accept "I took the chance to postpone it"

definitions.definition: experience or be affected by.
examples: the lad took a savage beating

definitions.definition: tolerate, stand.
examples: I can't take the humidity

definitions.definition: react to or regard (news or an event) in a specified way.
examples: she took the news well
synonyms: cope with "Liz took the news badly"

definitions.definition: deal with (a physical obstacle or course) in a specified way.
examples: he takes the corners with no concern for his own safety

definitions.definition: (of a batter) allow (a pitch) to go by without attempting to hit the ball.
regard or view in a specified way.
examples: he somehow took it as a personal insult
synonyms: deem to be "do you take me for a fool?"

definitions.definition: be attracted or charmed by.
examples: Billie was very taken with him
synonyms: entertain; informaltickle someone's fancy "Shirley was very taken with him"

definitions.definition: submit to, tolerate, or endure.
examples: they refused to take it any more
synonyms: shoulder; Moreformalbrook; archaicsuffer "I can't take much more"

definitions.definition: assume.
examples: I take it that someone is coming to meet you
synonyms: suspect "I take it that you are hungry"

definitions.definition: make, undertake, or perform (an action or task).
examples: Lucy took a deep breath

definitions.definition: be taught or examined in (a subject).
examples: some degrees require a student to take a secondary subject

definitions.definition: obtain (an academic degree) after fulfilling the required conditions.
examples: she took a degree in English

definitions.definition: require or use up (a specified amount of time).
examples: the jury took an hour and a half to find McPherson guilty

definitions.definition: (of a task or situation) need or call for (a particular person or thing).
examples: it will take an electronics expert to dismantle it
synonyms: involve "it would take an expert to know that"

definitions.definition: hold; accommodate.
examples: an exclusive island hideaway that takes just twenty guests

definitions.definition: wear or require (a particular size of garment or type of complementary article).
examples: he takes size 5 boots

definitions.definition: (of a plant or seed) take root or begin to grow; germinate.
examples: the fuchsia cuttings had taken and were looking good

definitions.definition: (of an added substance) become successfully established.
examples: be effective, take effect, hold, root, be productive, be effectual, be useful; Morework, operate, succeed, function; formalbe efficacious "the dye did not take"Morework, operate, succeed, function; be efficacious the dye did not take

definitions.definition: have or require as part of the appropriate construction.
examples: verbs that take both the infinitive and the finite clause as their object

definitions.definition: a scene or sequence of sound or vision photographed or recorded continuously at one time.
examples: he completed a particularly difficult scene in two takes
synonyms: clip "a clapperboard for the start of each take"

definitions.definition: a particular version of or approach to something.
examples: his own whimsical take on life
synonyms: approach to "a fresh take on gender issues"

definitions.definition: an amount of something gained or acquired from one source or in one session.
examples: the take from commodity taxation

definitions.definition: the money received at a theater, arena, etc., for seats.
an amount of copy set up at one time or by one compositor.
